Reviews.Title: Panasonic Plasma, need I say more?
Reviews.Author: Chris
Reviews.Content: Panasonic as far as I am concerned is the best producer of television sets in the world right now. Nothing compares to the picture clarity and quality of a Panasonic Plasma TV and this model is no different. I replaced a 42" Plasma from 5 or 6 years ago with this model and a week later I'm not even slightly regretting the choice.Update: Recently found out Panasonic has discontinued their Plasma models. If you're on the fence, make sure you decide before they are completely gone (I would NEVER recommend buying used Plasmas). Here is a great article from CNET with a summary of some very well spoken words regarding Panasonic and their Plasma line of TVs.[...]Presuming you do buy a Plasma this year from Panasonic, it should last you until the next generation of OLED TVs become reasonably cost affordable.Plasma technology has come a long way, you'll find that not only do you get the high refresh rate, deep blacks and crisp picture but you also get a longer lifetime now (~30 years of 8 hours a day viewing before the TV will begin to fade), much lower power consumption (CNET rates this model around $44 a year, Panasonic states $28, so figure it somewhere between $35-40 without using Eco-mode settings) and better picture control than in the past (multiple ratios, you can choose to cool/warm the picture in minute quantities and set different profiles for each input).Still, if you're sitting here trying to decide between a Plasma and an LED, you need to really only consider a few scenarios.If it is going to be in a family room that has bright lighting and won't be used for a lot of high action (sports) programming, you're probably better off going with a newer LED model for the screen reflectivity and to avoid the color saturation you get on Plasmas. If you want a Plasma and to avoid any serious glare problems, try stepping up a model to the ST60 or the VT60, each step up will dramatically improve screen glare (and add a crisper picture, which isn't terribly noticeable unless a side by side comparison is performed when in a scarcely lit room). Otherwise in a bedroom or somewhere you don't mind closing the blinds, this is a great buy. Update: Recently read about the P50S64 which has the anti-reflection coating on the S60 model here, try looking online to find your nearest dealer if this interests you.Trying to decide between the ST60 and the S60? Even I had a difficult time with that. The final decision really only came down to the fact that there isn't a noticeable difference in picture quality in the setting I have my TV and I don't need the Smart TV/3D ability.This model has Netflix, Amazon, Youtube, Hulu and a few other Apps. All of which are updated applications so the interfaces are more modern, which is nice. The Wi-Fi set up was very easy, so despite not being Wifi certified I wouldn't be concerned, it comes built-in and ready to go.Another great feature some Techies might find useful is full DLNA support with no complications. All I had to do was connect the network, pull up my DLNA apps on my Surface or Lumia 920 and boom, streaming right to the TV in all of its glory.Don't be fooled for other knockoff brands like Samsungs which just copy market innovators or LG/Sharp whom don't have the same technology built into their TVs like Panasonic does. The S60 is a great deal for the consumer, bringing affordable HD sets to the masses and backed by a brand that lasts, my TV still works from 6 years ago without ever needing a repair and I know of other people with Panasonics from 10+ years ago that never had problems.Update: I've seen a lot of people trying to find a magic configuration for their picture quality, but it's unlikely one settings configurations will match someone else's. Your best bet is to setup the TV and begin tweaking the main settings for your common programming. For instance, I watch a ton of hockey and like for the ice to be vivid and cool, I leave on CATS to dynamically adjust brightness from day to night, the human eye is only so precise so I wouldn't recommend obsessing over tweaks you can't actually recognize. Some people claim to see enhanced reds, pro settings can drop that level when you're in Cinema or Custom.

Reviews.Title: Extremely good picture quality and performance
Reviews.Author: Ace of Ben
Reviews.Content: After exhaustive research and subsequent comparison shopping, I decided on this TV in its 65" form factor. I am extremely pleased with the purchase (and subsequent Amazon delivery), and can recommend it heartily, especially considering its price point.Another reviewer echoed an important sentiment in these reviews to note if you're upgrading from an older TV: the performance of this set will almost undoubtedly trounce your older TV for a fraction of its original cost. In my case, a 2006 Panasonic 42" plasma that cost about $2,300 at the time; its picture quality and black levels don't hold a candle to this one.Also, going from 42" to 65" is like having a hallelujah chorus sing every time you turn it on. It's pretty glorious.Since picture quality is highly subjective, I will leave you to the professionals for their specific opinions and testing results (CNet has an informative review up). As for my personal opinion, the picture is stunning with Blu-ray and HD streaming content (Netflix, Amazon, and Vudu via the PS3). Gaming, specifically related to input lag and fluid motion, is an absolute joy to behold. The ST60 series was on my short list, but after the definitive input lag tests on those sets, I passed them up in favor of what I found to be a better deal in the S60 series.In terms of the visual aesthetic, this TV looks like a much more expensive model, with a particularly slim black bezel (it's about an inch) and understated stand. To quote one of my more eloquent friends, her first reaction to seeing the set when turned off was, "Whoa...fancy."Prior to purchasing, I spent some time trying to figure out if this TV would be too big for the space I wanted to put it in, and ended up addressing that question with about $4 worth of poster board stapled to the measured dimensions of the TV (for each size in this series you can easily find its specific measurements). I simply took the measured, combined pieces of poster board and held them up over my existing stand, and judged accordingly. And then grinned for about five minutes. To those of you debating a larger vs. smaller model, I'll relate one of the forum threads I found in which one of the early S60 owners simply said, "How often have you ever heard someone say they wish they'd bought a smaller TV?"The one serious knock (and honestly, the only legitimate knock I've heard against this TV) is that it is highly reflective in well-lit conditions. That point cannot be over stressed; this TV is not for you if you can't control your viewing room's lighting conditions. I hung blackout curtains in my home theater room (which I'd recommend doing regardless of your TV choice), and in those low-light conditions, the picture really shines. This TV becomes a mirror (a good-looking one at that) in bright conditions, so keep that in mind.All in all, I cannot recommend this TV enough, especially for the price point. I would suggest you go for a larger size if within your price range, and do what you can to control the lighting conditions in your viewing area. That's one particularly minor stipulation for an otherwise outstanding TV.

Reviews.Title: Great alternative to the ST60
Reviews.Author: Hayden Lindwall
Reviews.Content: After remodeling our basement and media room , we needed to find a nice TV. So the search began... We found that most of the LED options on the market were unacceptable. Horrible clouding and flashlighting, very poor black levels, etc... Plus, to get an LED TV that can compare to the picture quality of this S60, we would have needed to spend $3000+. At first we were hesitant to go plasma because of "burn-in", thickness, and some other issues on older models. I can assure you those issues no longer exist on modern plasmas.I was originally drawn to the ST60 instead of the "base model" that is the S60. However, the input lag is awful on the ST60. It is very annoying for any sort of video gaming. I found that with the S60, the difference in picture quality is negligible and the lack of input lag is a HUGE advantage. I realized that I will never use 3D and that my Mac mini and Xbox have all the apps I could ever want/need- so I picked up the S60.Let's start with the picture quality- it is fantastic. Turn off Eco-mode and you're set. There are some great settings on AVSForum if you want to dial it in and make it even better. But even the stock settings will look amazing to 95% of people. Blacks are extremely deep and colors are vibrant. After watching the S60, it is amazing how washed out picture looks on our LED TV. It's almost unbearable to watch after getting used to the S60. Not sure what else to say regarding PQ- you won't be disappointed.Other things:Design- I think it looks nice on the wall. Not the most beautiful TV ever made, but still very nice and the frame is very small. It has a nice profile.Glare- I was originally going to get the 65S64, which is the S60 with the anti-glare filter from the ST60, but they sold out everywhere. Glare has not been an issue even with all of the lights on in our basement. If you have it in a room with a ton of windows, and no blinds, or if it is going poolside in the backyard- this may not be the TV for you. Basically as long as you don't have direct sunlight that you can't control, you shouldn't have an issue.Overall, the S60 is a home run. We are picking up another S60 for the living room next week. I really believe it is the best value on the market today.

Reviews.Title: Replacing Viera 50" bought in 2006 for 1/3 of the cost
Reviews.Author: mr engineer
Reviews.Content: It replaces a 2006, 50" Viera and seems to be the same quality product but a lighter and smaller set built around the same screen size.  It was delivered to my living room and set up and checked.  I was very happy with the delivery.  The set has an improvement that lets you directly access internet movies from several vendors by using my wireless network in-house server.  I am not much of a pay-per-view person but U-tube videos are free.  The only drawback compared to my older set is the lack of a reflection free screen.  The older model featured some type of coating that stopped the mirror effect of lighting on the screen.  The new screen acts like a mirror and reflects lighting brightly.  Not good. The preference and set up menus are more elaborate to walk through than the older system but offer more.  Overall I feel the reliability will be good in this set as it has been in the past with no service needed for 6 years.  I gave my old set to someone and it was working like the day it was delivered in 2006.

Reviews.Title: Plasma as PC Monitor
Reviews.Author: Lynn
Reviews.Content: Don't let the stories of image retention or burn in sway you from purchasing Plasma as your primary PC monitor. I currently use the 60S60 as a home theater PC monitor for gaming, movies, and internet. Picture quality and "input lag" were the only two concerns while I was shopping for a new monitor. IMO Plasma delivers the best PQ versus equivalently priced LCD, LED. Input lag was a concern of mine for gaming, particularly fast paced games and first person shooters. After much research I found the 60S60 to have one of the better response times on the market.A few things you must be aware of:- Plasmas can be "broken in" for maximum PQ. I did this by running color slides off a USB drive for the first 100 hours- Plasmas can be calibrated. I found some generic calibration settings on the Internet. Alternatively, you can purchase the "Disney WOW" calibration Blu-Ray - great product, cheap- Soap Opera Effect: If your picture is too sharp/giving you the Soap look, you can adjust the settings to look exactly like the standard television. Search the Internet for help here.- Plasmas have a slight buzz from the rear of the panel. Not noticeable unless I walk behind the panel- Plasmas infrequently generate a feint "pop" sound, similar to a house settling. This is normal- Plasmas run warm- The 60S60 has a very reflective screen, not great for bright rooms1 Month Later:After using the set for 1 month I am extremely happy. No image retention after gaming, even with set HUDs. No input lag on any game. Great picture quality. Thinner and lighter than I expected. Love the ability to set each input with its own picture settings.

Reviews.Title: Great basic plasma with large screen for affordable price
Reviews.Author: Bruno "Bruno"
Reviews.Content: This is our 3rd Panasonic plasma TV.  Two 50's preceeded it.  This 65" model was a great value for the quality at $1500.  You must tweek the video settings to get the best out of it, however.  The standard setting is too dim and the CATS system just doesn't work well, so turn it off.  Play with it till you get it right and you'll be rewarded.  Our other units are 2 and 4 years old and have had no problems.  The built-in wireless internet and apps like Netflix/YouTube are awesome for the price you pay.  It's also surprisingly light for such a big screen (85 lbs!) and about 40% thinner than our previous units.Negatives:1.  On such a large screen, even at 1080p if you sit too close you may find the picture almost "blurry" compared to smaller sets.2.  Only two HDMI (fine with me), but it can be limiting with some setups.3.  No RCA audio out for older or more basic devices such as wireless headphones for Xbox, only optical audio out.  Work-arounds exist, though.4.  Some may not like the expensive looking metal trim on the edge if they want an all-black setup.  Again, I could not care less.5.  There is some reflection if you have a lamp on behind you or it's bright in the room.  Just place light sources further to the flanks of the unit and the problem vanishes.6.  Still tweaking, but picture may not be as sharply focused as our 50" models.  This may also be due to the huge size of the image, where you notice flaws in the signal more than on a smaller TV.We went with it for the quality, reliability, and vivid image vs LCD/LED TV's.  We've had two of those and were disappointed with both, one of which died after a year of use.I would highly recommend Amazon's enhanced delivery and buying direct from Amazon.com rather than other sellers here.  They bring it in and set it up so there is no question about a broken unit being an issue.  We tried another 60" unit from another (highly rated) seller and it arrived with a cracked screen.  It's been a hassle getting it picked up and a refund issued.  Also, there are some reports that warranties on non-approved sellers are not honored.  Amazon sends your unit out in a smaller truck that can actually get in your driveway manned by experienced TV delivery men.  Others just ship it freight in a huge semi truck  and hope for the best.  In our case they didn't even call first, but showed up at 10pm!!! on a Saturday night with a huge rig and we had to actually help them get it in.  In our case, even the seller recommended we not try them again, as shippping cross country such a delicate device there was plenty of chance of a box getting dropped or mishandled and I assume they were not relishing having to file a claim with the shipper again.

Reviews.Title: Excellent TV, especially for the price
Reviews.Author: Nicholas Decinque
Reviews.Content: I ordered this tv for $669 with free shipping. CEVA did a wonderful job getting the TV to me and was right on time with everything they told me. I'm not sure what kind of complaints people would have with the shipping company, but from what I experienced they were wonderful. I also only live 10 miles from their distribution center, so maybe if you live very far away from a center they may be more difficult to work with. The TV came packaged in a very large shipping box, and inside of that box was the TV box. Everything was very secure and undamaged. Lots of foam protecting everything.Exterior:I have the 50inch TV. It's a good size TV. Weighs around 60lbs. It's rather difficult for one person to pick up and set up, but it can be done. The design is very nice, a little understated. It's thicker than a nice LED, but it's thin enough to not matter that much.Sound:I'm actually impressed with the way the speakers sound on this TV. They are much better than I thought they would be. Perfect for any normal circumstances and video games. For movies I still use my surround sound system. You have a myriad of sound options so you can tweak whatever you want. The sound comes out crisp, clear, and can get very loud. Of course if you need some good bass and multi channels then get a sound system.Features:It only comes with 2 HDMI inputs. I don't mind it that much, but I can see it being a problem if you have multiple devices that need to be plugged in. It has built in wifi and an Ethernet connection. It also has digital audio output which is nice. Nothing out of the ordinary as far as inputs/outputs go, but you can't expect a lot from a sub $700 TV. There are enough menu options to keep almost everyone satisfied. You can tweak every setting that you would possibly want. It does have a couple of internet apps. Netflix, Amazon, Youtube, a few more. The apps are a little slow, but work very well. We use our smartphone to control the youtube app on the TV. It makes it much easier and makes browsing youtube just as easy as it is on the computer.Picture:THIS TV WON"T LOOK GOOD UNTIL YOU TWEAK THE PICTURE SETTINGS. This is a common complaint that people can't seem to understand. For starters, there is an eco mode on this TV (and a lot of other tv's). What this mode does is it dims the brightest and contrast down automatically, so it basically washes out everything and makes it look terrible just to save some power. When you go to a retail store (Best Buy etc...) and see this TV I promise that the eco mode is turned on and that's why the TV might not look so good. If you can ask an employee for the remote and turn the setting off. Once the stupid eco mode is turned off, you can make this TV look spectacular. There is a pre-loaded setting on the set called "Vivid" and it looks great. Colors are so pure and blacks are as black as can be. Seriously the blacks on this are as black as possible. This is the best picture I've seen on a TV under $1000, maybe even under $2000. An again, once you turn the eco mode off, the TV is plenty bright enough and the whites are very nice.Bad Stuff:The TV (like most plasmas) does make a little bit of white noise from the panel. You can't hear at normal volumes over the tv, but if you have the volume low then you can hear it. THE GLARE IS NOT AN ISSUE. If you have blinds of curtains, don't worry about the glare on the TV. If for whatever reason you always have light in the room then you may want to get the S64 from Costco (same TV with the antiglare coating). But the glare has never been an issue in my living room. However it does look bad at Best Buy with all of the bright overhead lights.Verdict:BUY THIS TV. As far as I'm concerned, this is the best TV under $1000. Don't hesitate to pick it up, and be aware that the TV will look much better in your living room than it does in the showroom of a store.

Reviews.Title: SOMETHINNGS ARE NEVER WHAT THEY SEEM.
Reviews.Author: PondKeeper "PondKeeper"
Reviews.Content: I bought this set locally because I sell them at a retail store. Customers always run to the LCD or LED TV's because they are the brightest. None in my opinion are as black or as accurate in color as this TV or any other plasma set.  Next time you shop in a brick and mortar store always look at the colors green, and the flesh tones,  plasmas produce a natural greens, NOT a phosphorous looking color green and movies look like 35mm film not the appearance of being shot on a video camera. If they look like just a video than you will see that in the lack of good flesh tones. Look for blacks and greens if they are right chances are you will be happy with any TV. Brightness could be factor, but all plasmas are generally dimmer than other types. But way more accurate regardless of 60,120,240 HZ rates. Except blue ray disc and gamers will provide 1080P most are interlaced at 1080I.

Reviews.Title: great tv
Reviews.Author: anonymous
Reviews.Content: This is a great tv. The picture quality is amazing, and setup is really easy. I was looking for a no-frills tv, without 3D.  The tv connects to your wifi, and its ready to go. It connects to netflix, and has a connection to other online movie providers (Amazon, hulu, you tube,etc.).  The only slight issue is that there is no filter on the screen, so if there is light, you'll see a reflection on the tv. It doesn't bother me, but know that it happens. And it's really not too bad, but it might bother some folks.  For the price and quality, it's a good buy.

Reviews.Title: PS4 and Xbox One certified!!! they both run amazing ..no lag
Reviews.Author: Tara Soper
Reviews.Content: Seriously for the money you spend, you won't find a better deal on this planet. This TV only has about 20 hrs of usage time but Im already amazed of the out of box picture quality its outstanding. Then I looked the model # up on cnet .com and used their inputted professional picture settings, and was completely blown away with the black levels..sure their are TVs that are better but they'll have to cost a lot more to match . I strongly advise a look into this TV before they get discontinued. ( only because 4k ,UHD, OLED, are here and will eventually come down in prices with expansive models, plus plasma s tend to use more energy then modern day LCDs and LEDS

Reviews.Title: Good Value For Dark Rooms
Reviews.Author: J.T.K. "Tony No Baloney"
Reviews.Content: This is a nice TV with a very good picture, IF, it is placed in a dark room and the lighting is carefully controlled in order to minimize the reflections. Otherwise the reflected images overpowers the programming and it is nearly impossible to watch. It has a pretty basic feature set as far as settings and apps but they were adequate for me since I would be happy with a true monitor because most of the sources for content require a second box anyway whether it be cable, bluray, satellite, or a Roku type box.  But a 65" plasma in the $1300 price range is hard to ignore IF YOU HAVE THE RIGHT ROOM!

Reviews.Title: Excellent picture once you spend time adjusting it...
Reviews.Author: Stu Ross
Reviews.Content: This TV comes with three (standard, cinema, and vivid) picture modes but none of them were suitable to my viewing preferences.  As someone who watched a lot of live sports on an LCD TV for the past 6 years, I have had a bit of an adjustment to watching them on this plasma set.  Since getting the set about a month ago, I have spent a significant amount of time tweaking the contrast (94) and brightness (+20) settings in order to get the picture to be as bright as I am used to.  Once you get this right, the picture is outstanding and you get the rich black tones that appeared as a very dark brown on my old LCD set.I had heard that plasma is a better technology for fast motion video like sports as well as avoiding the "wash out" effect when viewing from an off center viewing angle.  Although the wash-out effect is no longer an issue, I have had significant issues with the glare from the windows in my room reflecting off of the screen when watching the TV on weekend afternoons.  If you are planning to use this set in a very bright room, I would consider a matte screen alternative set or look at an anti-glare screen product online.

Reviews.Title: INCREDIBLY GOOD (Except For... )
Reviews.Author: Scott E. Bruneau
Reviews.Content: I researched TV's on CNet and this Panasonic sounded great. The price was excellent and there was a bonus with it I will write of later in this simple review.I was at a loss about the policy that Amazon has of a shipping company delivering on a set date; carrying the TV into your home and setting it up to make sure it works right. That is what happened with me. CEVA did all of that and at a very convenient time. Set it up and made sure it was working and left. What was VERY IMPRESSIVE was no dings dents or rips on the box. The box was big enough to fit a shetland pony in (ok not THAT big but you got the idea). The TV itself was in a box within with much packing material. THAT I liked. ALL of the packing was good. Once I turned the TV on, the instructions were SIMPLE. It is very intuitive and EASY. I got the TV primarily for watching movies. I have set it to Theatre mode and it is an INCREDIBLE AWESOME PICTURE! I never believed any image could be so good on a TV let alone on such a big thing. "Big" is what this is. The narrow black margin around it makes it look even larger. There is a delightful humility to the TV. It fades in the background so you can focus on what you are watching. It is low key. It does not shout at your eyes that "YOU ARE WATCHING A PANASONIC TV!". It shows you what you want to watch and NOT the TV.I think this is a BARGAIN if you have Amazon Prime. Free shipping this way. I have no idea what it cost to send it via a great company like CEVA. I am sure it was over $30. Considering the cost of a year of Prime... it makes the purchase a BARGAIN in my view. CEVA did a great job handling the product.As CNet had noted, 2 HDMI and 2USB ports. This is fine. It lacks the NUISANCE of so much extraneous BS. In conclusion... so far one of the best purchases I have ever made in my life.(NOTE ADDED LATER: There ARE a couple of  Nuisance  NEGATIVES to some if you want to use headphones and listen to TV or use the net with it. There IS NO HEADPHONE JACK WITH THIS! PANASONIC ENGINEERS SCREWED UP! There is I think a work around for it in purchasing a converter box (B003XCHCLC I have ordered the latter an hopefully it will work. The other negative is that yeah if you want to get content off the net you have to have a wifi connection. A no brainer I should have thought of duuuuh! So... Apple Express for wifi an extra $100 + the converter which is another $42 + a cable... easily an extra $150. The Add on's add up) But the TV is fine if you don't want to use wifi or headphones with it ;-)

Reviews.Title: This one is a keeper!
Reviews.Author: Kevin Beuret
Reviews.Content: A few months ago my first big-screen TV started tinting everything green, and since the fault couldn't be repaired I started shopping for another unit.  It took me a while to get past my reservations about plasma TV's--the early ones generated a lot of heat, and in time the picture faded--but once I investigated the newer models I became convinced that plasma was the way to go.  I was not mistaken.  This particular model is first-rate in every respect.  The picture is sharp and clear, the color is brilliant (though it will need adjusting when you install the TV), and, unlike my rear-projection TV, there's no light bulb to replace.  The only possible drawback to this TV is its reflective screen, but that's a non-issue.  Depending on its placement, you can easily draw the draperies during the day to avoid reflections, and at night a subdued light source off to one side accomplishes the same result.  With an HD source the picture is so good that, for example, when watching a basketball game you can see the crowd as individuals, and the tight shots of players in consultation with their coaches show everything--the texture of the uniforms' fabric, the beads of sweat on the players' faces, and even the stubble so fashionable among today's younger men.  I recommend this unit highly.  For such a great TV, the price is amazingly low, and to this point I have no reservations at all  about having purchased it.

Reviews.Title: LCD vs Plasma
Reviews.Author: Mark C.
Reviews.Content: My only comparison is a four year old Sony 50" LED. I had to have a backlight or my eyes would hurt from the excessive brightness coming from the tv even with the brightness down. Still the tv was consider a very good tv and I had it adjusted to Cnet specs for the best picture short of professional calibration.  This new Pany TC-P65S60 is so different with blacks actually being blacks, with the colors being pretty amazing, the whole picture being very easy on the eyes with no backlight needed. Sorry I can't be of more help for comparisons to other Plasmas but I just know this is a very good price of $1499 purchased at Best Buy for a 65" tv with such a good picture. I do have to mention the TV's reflection being great so if you have a bright room where you can't get a good darkness in your viewing area you might want to go with another tv. But for those who have good control of ambient light this tv rocks.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic p60s60 Plasma HDTV
Reviews.Author: Ronald D. Harry
Reviews.Content: I did a lot of reading [CNET reviews, magazines etc], visited retail stores, talked to friends before deciding I wanted Plasma and without all the latest bells and whistles like 3D and I already have wifi internet.  More than one friend said they could 'see' remnants of 3D interlace [assume they meant passive] where the picture seemed more jittery without the glasses.  Then the active 3D actually manipulated the glasses to sort of 'unsynch' each eye through very fast shuttering.  Didn't understand the technology completely, but suffice it that I did not want to be 'locked' into having to use glasses just to watch TV.  Articles emphasized that normal 2D was not altered without the glasses, but then, as mentioned, some friends told a different story.  My lean on 3D is that it is a passing fad, but I could be wrong; but I didn't need it.So, I went after the very best Picture quality within my budget to replace my old Samsung 60inch DLP [the core dlp chip went bad and Samsung was not assuming any liability for what they admitted were 'bad' chips; hmmm...a $2000 TV should last more than five years shouldn't it].  Anyway, the Panasonic P60S60 was exactly what I was looking for, with high reviews [at that price level], 2013 technology, with just the right amount of wifi connectivity that would be useful to me.WOW is all I can say about this unit's picture quality.  Wow again.  This is what HDTV is 'really' all about. Everything looks like 'blu ray' crystal clearness...you know, where it just jumps out at you.  I wish I could articulate it better...but Crystal Clear is all I can think of.Now, before you buy this set, make sure of the number inputs you will need, as this one offers only a kind of 'bare bones' connectivity, such as only 2 HDMIs, one component, a opitical sound output...and that's about it [well, with the standard coax from cable box connection no one uses since HDMI came out].  That was PERFECT for my setup.  But if you have a blu ray player, maybe a computer, or some other HDMI device, well, only 2 HDMI's could be a deal breaker.But that picture quality...WOW; I cannot imagine it being any better even in top end models such as panasonic has such high reviews for. I got exactly what I wanted, paid what I consider a fair price, and Amazon delivered timely and all intact.  Since I've only had this unit several weeks, I can't comment on the longevity, but at this point, I am well pleased, a satisfied customer.  Wow again [on the picture clarity]; sharp.

Reviews.Title: Incredible value.  And plasma has always been a challenge in bright rooms...
Reviews.Author: GoBoSox "nakiejakie"
Reviews.Content: I often wonder about the lack of common sense from reviewers with some wonderment about plasma technology.  Since its inception, plasma has struggled with reflection because of the glass panes used versus the LCD "screens" that have much less difficulty diffusing light.  Several generations in, plasma still and will always have that challenge.  Many of the higher priced plasma lines use filter to try to reduce glare but the fact is that some people say that in some way alters their viewing experience.  So pick your poison.Fact is that plasma comes the closest to duplicating the CRT experience that has traditionally produced the best pictures but cannot possible be made to work with flat screens. The most expensive LCDs struggle to match the almighty black levels that plasmas have used as their edge on LCDs for several years.  All that being said, I've owned several plasmas (at least 8) and have also owned a Sony SXRD that was considered ground breaking just 3 years ago.  I've had LGs (and still do) and several Pannys in the past.  Owned the 800U that was considered just second to the vaunted Kuro back in 2009.  I also have viewed Sammys in friends' houses.This Panny is by far the best value that I've seen bar none.  To get a 65" plasma for a shade under $1200 delivered even two years ago was unthinkable.  Somehow, Panny has found economies of scale and removed the gimmicky and virtually useless 3D add-on to hit that price point.The picture has outstanding black levels.  Excellent corner to corner linearity.  And deep, rich colors that belie its price.I tried 3D and found so few titles actually worth watching with actual 3D that was worthwhile that I returned the unit for this unit and have never looked back.  For reference, it's hooked up to an Oppo BD103D (the newest Oppo), DirecTV, Roku 3, and fed through a Denon AVR 3313ci.  Not audiophile level, but not entry either.Overall I give this TV the highest recommendation without reservation.

Reviews.Title: One week in...
Reviews.Author: R. Alexander "Tech enthusiast."
Reviews.Content: After one week I am thrilled with this TV. Months ago I spent a lot of time researching the GT & ST versions, thinking that the S60 would be too far down the totem pole for me to want. Fortunately, the GT & ST versions were too expensive for me so I put the whole purchase on hold.Then I came back for more research and started digging in to what the real-life differences are between the S60 and ST60. As it turns out, the differences are few and far between for my use.I use this TV in a basement with no direct sunlight hitting the TV, and recessed lighting; no light directly hits the screen. Because of this setup, I am not affected by any glare issues. The anti-reflective (AR) screens in the higher versions definitely came with a cost. I can certainly see that this TV is extremely reflective, though, but only when it's turned off (and looks like a mirror). Overall, the glare has not been a negative for me, because of my particular setup.Some of the other benefits of the more expensive models I was willing to live without. Years ago I bought a 50" Panasonic Plasma from Costco - it was as low-end as they made them. But, I always thought the quality was amazing (even compared to other Plasmas and LCD TVs). I figured, if I'm going from a low-end Panny to a low-end (bigger) Panny, then I won't know what I'm missing. Sure enough, that has been the case. I've been very satisfied with the picture quality.I use an AV Receiver for sound, so I am unable to comment on the quality of the Internet apps (the sound for internet apps only goes through the TV, not the receiver). I can tell you that they work, but I have very limited experience with them.One word to describe the TV? Value!! I got the 65"  TC-P65S60 for $1288.00. The higher models go for 50% and 100% more (and even more for VT). I am extremely please with my purchase and so glad that I took the extra time to look at the S Series, in addition to the ST & GT.

Reviews.Title: Great picture, easy set up.
Reviews.Author: Lathrop Bob "Bob"
Reviews.Content: This TV replaced an 8 year old LG plasma that finally died.I bought this same TV a year ago for a family room TV. That one was last years model. This TV has some great improvements over last years. The built in WiFi was a snap to set up. No external WiFi unit needed like the last one. Picture quality is sharp and amazing. The weight of this TV is about half of the original Panasonic 50" plasma I bought about 6 years ago.

Reviews.Title: Very Impressive T.V.
Reviews.Author: RH45011
Reviews.Content: We were upgrading from our expensive 50" Toshiba DLP television after it gave out and we were tired of buying $200 bulbs every 8 months. This panasonic t.v is amazing. The picture is very rich (I'm a graphic designer, so having a great picture and true to color performance is important to me.) blacks are rich blacks and colors pop. This tv has really cool features and I'm sure a lot more that we don't know about yet since we just got it 5 days ago. We have watched Netflix straight from the tv, perused my pictures from my USB and played XBOX on here.Games are amazing on here. Call of Duty and NASCAR show so many details that we never were able to see on our old tv. We were both asking each other "did you ever notice that before" or "look at those shadows!" I could see people coming around corners on COD before they came! I never was able to do that before! Simply amazing. My husband ran the white screen after playing for several hours, so far everything is awesome. Burn in was the only thing I was afraid of with plasmas, so hopefully that won't be an issue.So far, awesome color, features and price. we love it.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Picture - Best value out there!
Reviews.Author: TW "UTB!"
Reviews.Content: Firstly, I am not a big reviewer of products, but I am a research hound.  I was looking for great picture without all the bells and whistles.  I did not want 3D and already have a Roku3 for all the apps in the world.The quality of the picture compelled to comment on this great TV.First: $699 can't be beat.Second: the picture quality is amazingThird: Amazon TV delivery service is 1st class.Fourth: calibrate the picture as per the review from CNET.com and you cannot go wrong.Do be aware that the glass is very reflective, so be careful if you have a light source that will reflect on the glass (i.e. in front of the TV). We have found that side lighting does not interfere.I have set mine up with a Roku3 and together we have the best apps, the best picture quality and pretty good (definitely not great) sound.Highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: great!
Reviews.Author: T. Esmanech
Reviews.Content: I just received it, connected it and it works great, a big upgrade from my previous DLP one.It is the perfect TV if you are not looking for 3D and all the "smart-tv" features, though it does come with youtube, amazon and netflix.The contrast is super great, great blacks.I was initially worried about the reflection in a bight room, and I just have to lower the shades. It is more than acceptable.I do raccomende it.

Reviews.Title: Awesome picture but screen is like a mirror.
Reviews.Author: JFLY
Reviews.Content: Right out of the box the picture quality is awesome, great black levels, contrast and color. The thing that didn't work for me is that the screen reflects a lot (I posted 2 pictures in the product gallery). The tv was in a basement with no windows, recessed lights and everything reflects even is the scenes are not dark (refer to pics), so unless you plan on watching tv with the lights off all the time this tv is perfect for that. Unfortunately this was the deal breaker for me and I had to return it and got the ST60 which fixed the problem and I couldn't be happier.Oh yeah, another thing, the HD amazon streaming quality is lower than Roku's quality, same as the VT50 which I also have. The new ST60 HD amazon streaming quality is awesome and is just like the Roku's quality or even better. I only tested with amazon because that's all I have at the moment.Some people might be ok with the reflection and I thought I was going to be ok as well but that wasn't the case, the screen filter makes a huge difference. Obviously this is my personal opinion.Good luck everyone  :)

Reviews.Title: Great plasma image, but dim compared to plasmas of the past--uses aggressive ABL
Reviews.Author: M. Trotter
Reviews.Content: First, let me say I bought this TV to replace a Toshiba 50" plasma that finally died after about 6 years, and I also have a 42" Panasonic plasma in a guest bedroom.  The Toshiba plasma was able to achieve a pretty bright, contrasty image, even on bright content.  I also, 3 or 4 years ago, bought and installed a 55" Panasonic plasma that has a fantastic bright and bold picture for my parents.  So, I do have significant experience with plasma TVs.  I ended up returning the 60S60 due to the below issues.The problem is that, in an effort to increase longevity and to reduce energy consumption, the new Panasonic plasmas aggressively utilize ABL, which will dim the screen whenever there is a lot of bright or white content on the screen.  This results in whites becoming sort of a light gray tone, and people's faces appearing dull and lifeless.  No amount of adjusting the settings was able to ameliorate this effect. Perhaps this would not be an issue for younger eyes than mine, but I found myself straining to really see the image well, and my eyes test out at 20/20.The Panasonic 60S60 does produce fantastic colors and black levels, so if one has a dark room, and mainly watches Blu-ray or streamed movies it represents a great value.  But if one watches a lot of news and sports programming, the constant dimming of the picture could be a problem.  Now, the Samsung 8500 series plasmas do produce a much brighter image and have less aggressive ABL, but are going to cost you much more.  I never thought it would happen, but at this point I am researching and trying to find a LED TV with a combination of decent blacks and brights, along with acceptable motion performance.

Reviews.Title: Good tv but too hot
Reviews.Author: Rob
Reviews.Content: Very nice picture and very bright. User friendly and overall looks great. The only problem was that it ran too hot. It was a big problem for me as I live in a warm area and the screen would get extremely hot. When the screen has a lot of white color, it gets super hot. Not so much when it is black or dark. The heat was noticeable and significantly warmed up the tv room. Otherwise it was a great tv at a great price

Reviews.Title: Excellent Choice for a Large Plasma
Reviews.Author: Jason O.
Reviews.Content: I did a significant amount of research prior to this purchase.  I read a lot of reviews (Amazon, Crutchfield, CNET, and others), studied the specifications, filtered through the comparisons of plasma vs. LED/LCD, and ended up choosing the Panasonic plasma for the following reasons:1.  Our living room is not exposed to significant direct light (uncovered windows, skylights, etc.), and the majority of our viewing time takes place in the evenings in a darkened room watching either Blu-Ray discs or HD programming.  Picture quality took precedence over brightness offered by the LED/LCD displays.  This was a major factor in my buying consideration.  I would echo the warning of "beware the glare" if you have a bright room with a lot of reflected light / open windows and you plan on daytime viewing.2.  Picture quality was my primary buying consideration, and the color depth and image representation were extremely well reviewed.  Yes, there are TV's with higher resolution, but the majority of ratings and reviews put the picture quality on par with the flagship models from a number of manufacturers.  This is significant, given the price point variances.3.  The plasma had slightly better viewing angles, and was exceptionally well rated for uniformity, color, and deep black levels.  Again, you can find slight improvements in the quality compared to more expensive models, but to me the difference wasn't significant enough to warrant the increase in price.4.  I opted out of selecting a 3D TV (although available in the ST60 series) based on content availability, my lack of personal motivation to find and maintain the "right" 3D glasses, and the price difference.  Additionally, the Panasonic ST60 series was rated with higher input lag, a potential issue for game image rendering5.  The Panasonic offered a moderated version of the "Smart TV" - internet connectivity for my favorite providers (Amazon, Netflix, etc.) without a jumble of apps and advertisements to sift through.  Simpler being better, in my opinion.Enough of the research notes, though.  Let's get down to the actual review:I LOVE this television.  It stacks up to the excellent reviews and is a joy to watch.  The sheer scope of the 65" screen is astounding, and it provides visibility to a whole new level of detail, especially with Blu-Ray movies.  This is especially evident with epic action-adventure movies like Pacific Rim, The Avengers, and the Transformers and Iron Man series.  "Inky blacks" and spectacular color bring a realism to screen images that elevates the entire viewing experience.  I paired this TV with an excellent home theater surround sound system and am enjoying re-watching my entire HD movie collection.There is some glare on the screen during mid-day from a sliding glass door directly opposite the television placement, but as indicated in # 1 above, the infrequency of day-time viewing was not enough to over-ride the picture / color quality trade-off.  Closing the blinds in front of the sliding glass door reduces the glare enough that it's not a distraction, but I recommend consideration of your viewing environment to ensure this isn't an issue.PS3 gameplay is smooth and the graphics are precise.  The opening image sequence from Injustice: Gods Among Us is nothing short of spectacular.  Fight sequences and cut scenes in God of War: Ascension are exponentially better.  Again, screen size supports a level of detail that changes the entire experience.  This holds true for games as well as the movies, where intricate details in character expression help "sell" the scene.If I could change one thing, I would add Rhapsody as an App native to the television, but I have access to the subscription service via my receiver.  All in all, I couldn't be happier with my purchase.  Affectionately dubbed the "BFT" (Big Freakin' Television), we love watching movies on the huge screen, are consistently in awe of the detailed imagery, and find it easy to get pulled into the stories.  It's great to have found a product that has such high quality at such a reasonable price.  Zero buyer's remorse.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic TV
Reviews.Author: Bill Chapel
Reviews.Content: Not much to say other than what has already been said. Picture is great.  I was a little worried about glare because my living room has a lot of windows, none directly across from the TV.  It works great. Just set it on vivid during bright days and cinema at night.The only thing I would suggest is that if you are flush mounting the TV, you buy some HDMI 90 degree elbows because the HDMI are set up to come straight out of the back of the tv, not on the side, if that makes sense.I run all HDMI through my receiver so I do not need more than one HDMI.  Its a fantastic television.

Reviews.Title: Amazing TV if you have an Xbox/PS3.
Reviews.Author: Metalmx
Reviews.Content: So as a stand alone unit, This TV is still an amazing value for the money. All the reviews about amazing picture quality are true. Yes the reflective nature of the panel is a bit of a downer if light is an issue. However, for a bedroom tv that is watched 80% during the night time it's amazing (and a good set of curtains does the trick during the day). All the smart features on other TV's are great if you don't already pay for the use of them on a game console. However i pay for the Xbox and it's live services. So why should I pay 1k+ for a tv that is redundant in features I'm already invested in? Amazons delivery was great and easy. Tv arrived in perfect condition and tested by the moving crew. I have this hooked up to the new Vizio 5.1 sound bar kit at costco (which is on sale this month!!!!). I have Wireless 5.1 surround in my room with great sound and a premium picture for under $1000 out the door.Even if you don't have a game console...Netflix/hulu/and amazon are the big three i use 90% of the time anyway. The only thing i really need the xbox for now is HBOgo.

Reviews.Title: Great TV for the money
Reviews.Author: Dan
Reviews.Content: I have only had this set for a couple of weeks now, but so far I am completely happy with it. It is the perfect size for the family room. I watched Django Unchained in Blu-Ray and the picture is awesome. So far I have not experienced anything I would categorize as a con. It is a Plasma, so you should be aware that the screen is extremely reflective if there is any light opposite the screen, and it is much better viewed in a dark room. I bought it for watching movies in a darkened room. The TV is pretty  heavy, so if you plan to hang it, make sure you have a strong helper. I would definitely recommend this to a friend.

Reviews.Title: Best value TV on the market
Reviews.Author: Matthew
Reviews.Content: This is my first plasma TV. I had been using a LCD monitor for gaming and a CRT TV nearly as old as myself to watch movies, but finally decided to bite the bullet when I heard about this TV.One major factor in choosing this TV was input lag. My grandparents have a $2000 Samsung LED TV that I've played some games on. The picture looks great but there is a 1/2 second delay between pressing a button on my controller and action happening on screen. Apparently this is a problem with almost all TV's... except the Panasonic S60. As soon as I had my TV hooked up I nervously loaded up a game and to my surprise there is 0 input lag! Its as good as my computer monitor!I put in a Blu-Ray and as advertised, blacks are completely black. Plasma TV's don't have a backlight like LCD/LED TV's so if a scene is dark it will actually be black instead of dark gray. Colors are also amazingly vibrant. Its like looking through a window. The only downside to the picture is if a scene is mostly white the TV will darken the picture slightly to avoid overheating. Its barely noticeable most of the time however.Protip: Turn CATS off and make sure the contrast is turned up to 100 for the brightest picture. I'd also disable all the anti noise filters, they remove some picture detail.One more thing to mention. The higher end Panasonic plasmas have an anti-reflection filter, which this one lacks. The screen is very reflective so its best used in a dark room.

Reviews.Title: awesome tv
Reviews.Author: tonywelp
Reviews.Content: the picture on this tv is fantastic right out of the box. the only thing i had to do was turn off the c.a.t.s.the c.a.t.s feature makes the picture too dim for me.for $699 from amazon this set eats the competition can't say enough good things about the picture.it also has wifi.i guarantee this is the best set for the money.it also works great on fast motion ps3 games just an awesome set.

Reviews.Title: Great television, Glare Issue is Overblown, Awesome Picture Quality for the Price
Reviews.Author: William B. Woodrum
Reviews.Content: Great television. I think the glare issue is overblown. I have the 60 inch version and it is just a great television with just enough smart features. Picture quality is very good for the price.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Plasma TV
Reviews.Author: Jtartaro
Reviews.Content: This TV is awesome. I got the TV when it was scheduled with no shipping damage. I installed in my bedroom and it worked perfectly. It is very easy to setup including WiFi. I did change it the network connection to wired, only because i get a full 100mb to the TV for streaming. Netflix, Amazon, HULU streaming is excellent and easy to launch and run. I installed a Samsung Blu-Ray player to it and the HD resolution on movies like Nemo and Toy Story as just superb.  If your thinking about getting a plasma, don't think about it, get this one. At 600 hz, the motion is floor-less.  The brightness has 4 setting for different light conditions in your room. I have not needed to set it on the brightest mode. My bedroom is on the east side of the house with 4 large windows and a 6x8 sliding glass door. During the day, I have no problems with TV brightness. One last comment, the view angle is just great. My bedroom is about 25 ft long by 18 ft wide. I can see a perfect picture from anywhere in the room. You will love it.

Reviews.Title: Even better than advertised!
Reviews.Author: Richard Staats
Reviews.Content: The picture is crisp and beautiful.It was easy to set-up.I have nothing but great things to say about this Plasma HDTV.

Reviews.Title: Best Tv I ever seen! No joke!
Reviews.Author: gary purdy
Reviews.Content: First off I bought this tv along with my Playstation 4 and good god! This TV is seriously incredible! The colors are amazing and Picture quality made my jaw drop! This tv does reflect but I never notice it as the uniformity, brightness and screen quality eliminate this issue. If your a gamer then buy this tv! I swear you will be very satisfied with your purchase! I love you panasonic!

Reviews.Title: Panasonic 65" TC-P65S60 comparison
Reviews.Author: Rodney N. Larson
Reviews.Content: I had this sitting side-by-side for days with a 70" Vizio LED/LCD, and hands down, the Panasonic Plasma 65" was better.  Yes, in my living room with several windows, during the day, there is more reflection, but it doesn't really bother me.  Overall, I'd take the pana plasma over an LCD.

Reviews.Title: Stunning picture quality, but no frills.
Reviews.Author: Shawn Hagewood
Reviews.Content: I have owned this TV for about 3 months now and as an audio/visual enthusiast, I can tell you that it is one of the most beautiful quality pictures I have ever seen.  It does not have 3D or lots of internet apps, but I don't use those anyway.  I primarily use this TV to watch cable TV/DVR, streaming and Blu-Ray movies and Netflix.  The TV does have Wi-Fi built in which is nice and works wonderfully with the Netflix app.  For the money, this is such a beautiful TV and at 65" looks amazing in our living room.1 CON:This TV is VERY reflective!  There is no anti-glare coating like on some plasmas and led TVs, but if you primarily watch TV at night or have a room where you can close the drapes, it's not too bad during the day.  However, even at night if you have lots of lamps and overhead lighting - you will have to turn them off or dim them down low... Unless you enjoy looking at your own reflection in the TV screen!

Reviews.Title: Panasonic TC-P65S60 65-Inch 1080p 600Hz Plasma HDTV
Reviews.Author: Testlight
Reviews.Content: All I can say is WOW. I must have searched & researched TVs for over a year before settling on this Panasonic. I will say that CNET reviews weighed heavily in my decision to purchase, along with the excellent price from Amazon! The TV is used in a well lit room with plenty of windows & outside light. While most of my viewing is at night, the daytime picture is still excellent, with minimal glare or reflections. After the 100 hour breaking period, I adjusted all picture settings with the Disney World of Wonder blue ray disc(also purchased from Amazon, & HIGHLY recommended). The picture is warm & life like. I am very satisfied with this purchase. It was worth the wait!

Reviews.Title: Panasonic TC-P65S60 65 inch HDTV
Reviews.Author: Narrah McCoy
Reviews.Content: Excellent picture. I have no trouble with reflection, as reported by some people.The only downer I have is the sound from the TV speakers. However this is to be expected.

Reviews.Title: Consumer Reports #1 TV for 2013 Lives Up To It's Reputation
Reviews.Author: Adam Mills Strom "Due South Productions"
Reviews.Content: Consumer Reports rated this #1 so I bought it.  I don't have a lot to compare it to other than my 2007 Samsung 720p Plasma.  But it looks better than that and even though I've been diligent about turning on the burn-in protection after every use; I yet to see one ghost image even after leaving menus on for minutes at a time.  Very impressed.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Picture, low price, low lag for games. However, TV audibly "pops".
Reviews.Author: Matthew
Reviews.Content: I wanted to buy the Panasonic ST60 but it suffers from extreme lag which is bad for games so I had to look elsewhere. I considered higher end Panasonic Plasma TV's but they have more lag than I wanted too. I looked at other brands, specifically the Sony KDL-55W802A and 55W900A. The 802A has an unimpressive picture and the 900A is unavailable in local stores to examine.I almost bought the Sony KDL-W900A sight-unseen but realized something. I could buy this TV (Panasonic TC-P50S60) for 1/4 the price, it has a great picture and there is no uncertainty in the purchase.Having owned this TV for a couple of weeks now, I decided to write this review. I won't bore you with details except to say I doubt there is a better TV anywhere close to it's price. The picture is fantastic. Way better than the Sony KDL-W802A I looked at in stores (or any of the other low-lag TV's I looked at in person).However, there are two caveats that keep me from giving it a perfect score of 5. The first is that the screen is extremely reflective. I knew this before buying it, but even in a light-controlled room I have had to make some adjustments to avoid reflections. The other problem I have with the TV is that it "pops" a lot. I believe this is heat expansion/contraction within the TV. It is annoying, but not so much to warrant a return. Periodically, there is a loud "snap" from the television, even after it has been turned off awhile.

Reviews.Title: Great low cost TV
Reviews.Author: Paulo
Reviews.Content: Great TV. The size does matter and the image is amazing. No reason to spend more on features you will never use. Very happy with the purchase

Reviews.Title: Excellent Black Levels and Super Fast Latency for Gaming.
Reviews.Author: Jeff D Mack
Reviews.Content: I ordered this plasma tv based on cnet.com's reviews and I couldn't be happier.  The Picture quality when watching darker movies(The Dark Knight, Sin City, Tron Legacy)look amazing and my K/D Ratio in Call of Duty has improved as well.

Reviews.Title: Don't look any further
Reviews.Author: Savvy Shopper
Reviews.Content: Not much to add to what has already been said. This TV reflects like a mirror but I knew this going in based on the reviews.  I have it in a basement with controlled lighting so that is no problem.  It will be an issue for you if you can't control lighting. The picture is awesome.  I own several HD TVs and this has the greatest picture so far. If you are like me and trying to decide between this and the next model up, save your money because this one does the job. I have a ps3, Xbox 360 w/hd player and they all look great. My kids do the gaming and there are no lag issues. Black levels are excellent.  Bottom line best value for my money which is what I look for in any product. Great TV.

Reviews.Title: TV great. delivery poor
Reviews.Author: Chris
Reviews.Content: The TV is great.  I love everything about it.  It was very easy to set up (you have to do that, the delivery people only turn it on to show it works) and it is very user friendly.  I was really buying the TV so I didn't let it affect my rating of the TV itself.  I'm sure Amazon uses all different delivery people, so you might have a better experience than I had.  My TV was delivered by Pilot.  They were terrible in their communications and shoddy in their delivery.  i have learned that Amazon simply reports what Pilot says.  Therefore, Pilot's website said the TV was "out for delivery" last Friday.  I then received a text from Amazon saying it was out for delivery and would come that day.  I took off an hour of work to be there.  Never came.  Pilot said it was actually given to a transfer agent or some such thing and would not be delivered that day.  Long story short, I got the TV Tuesday.  I received no communications not initiated by me until a phone call saying they were 2 minutes away.  They tracked dirt into my house, did not offer to take the box away ( i had already signed the checklist saying they had because I just wanted them gone).  Besides, I was fairly certain there were still items in the box I needed.  Very poor and not very professional.  Of course, there is no number to call Amazon on this.  All that being said, I love the TV, it is everything I wanted.  Beautiful picture, easy to set up.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful picture quality
Reviews.Author: Terry Weatherstone
Reviews.Content: This TV was in the top 5 recommended TVs on CNET.  It was the first of the top five with a price under 2500 dollars.It took some playing with the settings at first.  The picture was too dark and the brightness setting didn't seem to help.  We were on the edge of returning it, but we called Amazon tech support.  They identified the problem in about two minutes, and talked us through how to turn off the advanced black function.  Now we love it.

Reviews.Title: Good value for the money
Reviews.Author: Ralph Heimlich
Reviews.Content: I got an open box deal on this and it's exceeded my expectations.  I use it in a pretty dark space (basement rec room) so the usual knock on plasma TVs doesn't in well-lit spaces doesn't apply.  The colors are very good and the sharpness at 1080p is great.  The internet connectivity to U-tube, Netflix and other services is fine, but it doesn't have a true browser.  That's ok because I have it hooked up to an old computer with an HDMI cable for surfing and other computer needs (just like a 50" monitor).  Works great.

Reviews.Title: This is a winner
Reviews.Author: Bobby M.
Reviews.Content: Amazing picture and ideal for movies at night.  The glare can be an issue in the day, but that's the nature of plasmas.

Reviews.Title: Great!
Reviews.Author: Ed Lutterschmidt
Reviews.Content: I expected a good product from my research and wow, I got it.  This plasma HD is fantastic!  Picture, colors, ease of use, all are tremendous and can't beat the price.  Delivery was excellent also.

Reviews.Title: Great TV
Reviews.Author: Dan Bentley
Reviews.Content: I went from a 5 year old 720p 50" pannisonic plasma that i thought looked great and this is quite a bit better. I watched Avatar and the colors and contrast are fantastic. The picture is vibrant and clear. I am also amazed how close i can get to it and the picture still looks great. I haven't watched any standard def content so i cannot comment on that but the multiple movies I have watched wheather on Blu-ray or HBO HD have been wonderful. I was concerned about the reflectiveness of the screen but don't have a lot of light to worry about downstairs to worry about upgrading to a ST60. There is still some noticable reflections which curtains will take care of over the one window depending on the seating location. Overall a great value for a big TV. The bezel is small and looks much nicer than my previous Panasonic. I would recommend this to anyone who can control the light in the room.

Reviews.Title: I got exactly what I was hoping, really should be used with Blu-ray and FHD content
Reviews.Author: Julian A. Lopez III
Reviews.Content: This tv needs to be used with FHD(1920x1080) content to really see how good it is. It saddens me to see people put anything less than 720p on it, and those channels with black bars :( . Also, just to be safe, DO the Break-in of at least 100 hrs of full screen movie/motion content, contrast below 50 for that time. The speakers are alright, with some adjustment they are decent, but they don't produce anything intelligible below 150hz. Use it in conjunction with an AVR speaker system. Only two HDMI inputs, more of a reason to get an HDMI AVR  if you plan to connect HDMI cable+ blu-ray+ game console. Or you could just plug and unplug an HDMI each time. So, no screen wash-out, no ghosting, endless color adjustment, pixel shifter, screen wipe, its the best(looking,dependable) for the price in Plasma Tvs.

Reviews.Title: Great TV
Reviews.Author: lockedout
Reviews.Content: It arrived as scheduled, Amazon's people did a great job setting it up, and the picture is great. Really like the optical output for sound, allowing me to run audio through my stereo system. Would definitely recommend to others

Reviews.Title: Just like the others
Reviews.Author: Ricky
Reviews.Content: This was my 3rd Panasonic Plasma and just like the others I love.  Its nice to know a product will be outstanding every time you purchase.

Reviews.Title: What a Picture Right out of the Box
Reviews.Author: Don Rich
Reviews.Content: Fantastic!  I have no use for 3d or a smart tv so this is just what the doctor ordered!.  Easy to set up, and the picture was fabulous right out of the box.  I highly recommend this Plasma!  Amazon did a Best Buy Price match.  This is a Panny at its best!

Reviews.Title: Excellent Television, don't buy the burn in hype.
Reviews.Author: Anonymoose
Reviews.Content: This is a fantastic set. When the price is considered it is an awesome value.I'm a gamer. I play a lot of games with static HUDS. Fighters, FPS, RPG, you name it. I spent time leaving this TV on with static images when I first got it to see if the burn in nonsense was true.The verdict: It is mostly nonsense. This TV WILL get very slight image retention. However it doesn't last long at all. Run the screen swipe, watch a full screen movie and it's gone. Also, when it is there it is very hard to notice. I was SO worried about this before I bought the TV but it is such a ridiculous scare tactic that I have to wonder if people right it because they are sociopaths that like to make other people sad. It is so ridiculous.The color reproduction in the set is pretty great. It beats my old LCD hands down. Black levels are impressive, colors are rich and accurate. I see no ghosting in anything.The only downsides:Only two HDMI ports. For real? This is just stupid.The screen has crazy glare. If you can't put up black out curtains covering black out blinds in the room  you have this TV in forget watching it during the day.Also, what people say about brightness in whites is true. Full white screens look dim. It sucks, but how often do you sit and stare at a white screen? While this a fair caveat I can't imagine it really means much to anyone.If you want BRIGHT during the day, buy an LCD. If you want an amazing picture and can control the light in  your room, buy this TV.Lastly, this TV has very few smart features which I personally thing is great. I find 3D and smart features to be worthless so it's refreshing to have a model that I'm not paying for that nonsense with.I can't stress enough how much burn in is NOT an issue. If someone is having burn in problems they are doing something wrong. Follow the break in steps when the TV is new. Create a DVD to run colors for a couple hundred hours after you go to bed. The color DOES improve when the phosphors are aged.Go to cnet to get calibration settings. It's easy and it makes a huge difference.Also, the picture is so good that at first you may think that it isn't. That sounds strange, but it's all about the source. If you are watching hi def, blur ray, playing an HD game, it's amazing. If you're feeding it a crappy signal it does not look good. However, if you're going to be watching SD content why are you buying an HD tv?

Reviews.Title: Amazing picture, just make sure it sits far away
Reviews.Author: Charles
Reviews.Content: Just sent back my Samsung LED LCD TV and picked this up instead. The Smart TV portion of the Samsung just wasn't there, and no point in paying extra for something I won't use when a HTPC/set top box will do it better.Saw the amazing reviews here and decided to give it a shot.If you have a choice of getting the S60 or S64, get the S64 it has an anti-reflective add in the S60 doesn't. Otherwise it's the same panel.My impressions:Pros- The most amazing thing about this is the blacks. This is my first plasma but I never knew how much the LCD backlights ruin the blacks. If you ever watch a movie with the black bars on the sides, in a lot of LCD's you can see the backlight shining through (usually from the edges). However with this, it literally blends into the darkness in the room if you watch at night. Most of the time I forget there are even black bars on the sides for my old content. The night time scenes in a lot of movies are taken to a whole new level and everything just looks better with darker blacks.- Colors. I swear my movies never looked this good before. It's like they've been replaced and upgraded themselves. I don't really know how to convey it, but everything just looks richer (not saturated) from what I am use to seeing.- The size is great. This is my first 50 inch TV and it's almost too big.- Reasonable price. I don't need Smart TV bull built in to add to the cost when I already have a HTPC and Roku that does it better.- Input lag is low due to the plasma technology. Gaming is responsive.Cons- Remote isn't backlit. Minor gripe.- It's grainy closer up. The plasma has lots of sub pixels constantly being moved (I assume to avoid picture burn in) that creates a noise effect throughout the entire screen. I could see it from about 4 feet away and the effect diminishes as you get further away. (After about 7 feet I couldn't see it), so make sure your TV sits that far away. I was told this is inherent in plasmas. It's not the source as it does this even in the OSD.- Has banding problems, which I was told is normal in most plasmas. This is the "Shades of Gradation" that they have listed. (Search 'gradient banding', for an idea on how this will look.) It is noticeable.- Buzzing. The TV has a buzz coming from it. Not that noticeable, but if you are sensitive to such things, it might annoy you. Apparently normal.- Dithering problems. Again, normal with plasmas.Note: You have to 'break' this TV in so to speak. For plasmas you have pictures or video playing constantly for hundreds of hours to get the plasma to properly adapt it's colors. Not really a con, just kind of a note.All in all the picture and colors are amazing, but there are a lot more cons with this plasma TV than I thought. I wasn't completely blown away like All in all, for someone putting this in a living room and over 7+ feet away, and don't mind banding, this is an amazing television that you should get.

Reviews.Title: Great TV!...
Reviews.Author: Buy Guy
Reviews.Content: Just as I expected. "Plasma...there is no substitute". So far so good....It's been hooked up for 3 days now and the picture is great!

Reviews.Title: Brightness concerns are not a problem - buy this set while it's still available.
Reviews.Author: Jeff Snavely
Reviews.Content: Great value!Concerns I read about input lag, brightness in lit rooms and screen reflection are all non-issues.Works great with Guitar Hero/Rock Band games (didn't need to use in-game calibration).TV is 6 feet from two large windows on the side with wood blinds and even during the day with one open I can watch it just fine. It is not as bright as an LCD but that is expected with Plasma.YouTube feature is very cool - I can search and send videos from my Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 to TV with ease (iphone didn't work well).Built-in Netflix works well (slow to boot up initially) but not as good as Roku.When you first set it up the screen is very dim in the "standard" picture mode but the other modes are much brighter.

Reviews.Title: Very impressive cost:performance ratio.
Reviews.Author: Sloan Ranger
Reviews.Content: Great deal. Great Picture. Looks better than LED especially for sports. I find the picture to be warmer and very deep blacks, not to mention for 1/2 the price. Great Shipping and Handling.

Reviews.Title: Happy Panasonic Plasma buyer, great picture quality. First Impression.
Reviews.Author: Rohan
Reviews.Content: I bought this TV (50") from Sears a day before thanks giving for $599+ taxes + recycling fee.  Very few people must have got this deal on this amazing TV. I had spent a lot of time researching TV on line and in store. I have spent hours in best buy looking at TVs.This is my very first foray into HDTV, and I am glad that I made this purchase. The picture quality is amazing, the rendering of colors is very natural as opposed to those LED tvs.Pros.1. TV is treat to look at, sleek design, nice metallic accent on top and bottom.2. TV is really easy to set up.3. Picture quality is really good as compared to other LED TVs (Not as good as 4K, which no one care at this time)4. Watch a blu-ray movie in dark room with home theater speaker system, you will never go to Theater again.5. I like the fact that it is not a full smart TV (it just has internet apps). I like to have pure TV experience. I have PS3 or WIDI for internet access and apps.6. Natural rendering of all colors.7. Blacks are really deep which makes it really good watching experience in dark room condition.Cons:1. TV is little heavy, which is not a problem for me, but might be for others.2. I use antenna, and this TV does not have good channel info feature.3. It does not show what programs will be coming next on my TV. (it used to show on my Samsung TV)4. Watching movie in bright lit room, gives you reflection.5. Netflix app is buggy(ask in comment why is it bad)6. Other apps are also not as good as they are on PS3.All in all very happy with the purchase.

Reviews.Title: Great Value for the Quality of the Picture
Reviews.Author: Rotary
Reviews.Content: Great Picture, Easy to set up, & delivered in perfect condition. This was my first plasma TV. I have been buying LCD TVs before. Due to the good review in a consumer web site I found on this TV plus other reviews I found on the net I bought this. I was very pleased with the picture. The set up was easy also.

Reviews.Title: Astonishing for $650
Reviews.Author: A. Reviewer
Reviews.Content: Spent a lot of time researching TVs. Attracted to plasmas due to excellent black levels and good motion handling. Ideally you will want your room to be dark and not have a lot of lights reflecting off the screen. Picture quality is excellent, make sure to do some tweaking outlined on various avs forums. Panasonic is the Plasma of choice on the market right now, its sad they won't continue making them. Got this when it was $650 and don't have a single regret. Make sure you feed this the best 720/1080p content you have access to.Oh yeah, buy some bookshelf speakers and a receiver. Don't use the built in speakers! Try Dayton or Micca for cheap loudspeakers and a lepai 2020a+ as a cheap stereo amp.

Reviews.Title: Only One Annoyance
Reviews.Author: Ericka Kahler
Reviews.Content: I am really enjoying my new television.  The picture on the television is great, but I had to adjust the display settings from the standard setting to get a decent picture.  The standard setting was too dim and the color quality was poor.  I also had to decrease the sharpness, since the factory setting was creating pixelation around the edges of objects.  It was well worth it to navigate through all the display options and customize the picture.I also like that this television is not a true Smart TV.  It makes getting to the apps I use most often easier, with a one touch button for Netflix right on the remote as well as on screen selections for Hulu, Amazon and You Tube.  I love to stream content and this TV has the ones I use most often without having to go through multiple menus.  The interfaces for the apps took some getting used to because I had a Roku box before and these interfaces are different than Roku's, but now I can find the content I'm looking for pretty easily.The television gets a 4 star instead of a 5 star rating because I find need to reconnect to the wi-fi signal frequently.  I tend to need to reconnect when I open an app for the first time after the TV has been turned off.  It doesn't usually lose the connection while I am using the television, but if I turn it off I expect I'll have to run the routine to connect to the internet again when I turn it back on.  I doesn't take long, but it is annoying.  If you do buy this television, I highly recommend using a wired connection rather than the wi-fi.

Reviews.Title: Awesome! Best value for the money
Reviews.Author: Theresa Greco "Food lover"
Reviews.Content: I cannot say enough good things about this television. I did my research before purchasing it. I went to cnet and winnowed down my choices; once I decided I wanted a plasma, I went with the Panasonic because of the picture quality reviews. I was not disappointed. This picture on this TV is simply incredible. I also went with the S60 because it has a basic version of Smart TV; I did not want to have to navigate through a plethora of menus just to be able to watch TV. I got exactly what I wanted. You turn it on, and you watch TV. You can access the Smart TV menu and select from six different apps; the Netflix app has its own button (which is the one I use 99% of the time, anyway). And, true to the reviews, there is a reflection issue (I knew that going into it, but wanted the picture quality). We have a rather dark room for it, so it's generally not too big of a problem. But if you have a room with a lot of sunlight, you might want some darkening shades; or maybe put it in another room. I have not had any "noise" issues with it. And, as some have stated, the Netflix app does take a minute or so to load up, but that doesn't really bother me. It only has two HDMI inputs, but that is all that I needed. I believe the newer models have four (not sure, but I think that's what I read), but I didn't want a newer one because I didn't want to have to work my way through the smart TV nonsense. If you watch a movie like "Avatar" or "Thor" on this with a good blu-ray player, the picture will literally blow you away. Also, like most new TVs, you don't really get the volume out of it. I bought a receiver to compensate for that; I think that's an issue with any of the newer flat-screens, though. Truthfully, I am pretty sure you could spend a lot more money and not get this much TV.

Reviews.Title: Excellent quality and value for the price
Reviews.Author: Petra Zales
Reviews.Content: Upgrading from a 32" 780p to the Panasonic TC-P50S60. Picture quality is great; although required some time adjusting the settings. Out of the box the image seemed to be too dim in a dark room. But after making minor changes it is prefect. I am a little disappointed with the sound quality; however with additional adjustments to the sound settings I was able to bring the sound to an acceptable quality. I haven't tested the built-in applications as I have a PS3 that already has all of the provided applications and more. I am really disappointed with the Android Remote Control application that can be downloaded from the play store on Google. However I do not hold that against the TV itself.  Excellent

Reviews.Title: Great TV!
Reviews.Author: Todd Griggs
Reviews.Content: After significant research, I decided to give Panasonic TV's a try and very glad I did.  I have a 60" Samsung PN60E7000 that I am comparing to.Pros: Good picture, good price, easy menus, simple setup, very quiet (no buzzing like some have), 65" is nice and big, optical audio out works great with sound bars!  Shipping company was prompt, on time and tested the TV before leaving to make sure it worked.  One reason I chose to purchase from Amazon was that you can easily choose what day to deliver.  With a TV this size, someone has to be there and to make sure everything works!Cons: Only 2 HDMI ports, thicker that Samsung.
